children.value: Impulse

What is impulse? When Newton described his second law of motion he said that an impulse causes a change in momentum in the direction that the impulse is applied. We often find it useful to discuss this law in terms of a 
resultant
 resultant force and the rate of change of momentum (or for constant mass 
$\valuedef{\vtr F}{m{\vtr a}}{}$
 ) but thinking in terms of an impulse allows us to take into account the length of time for which the force is applied.
How does the final speed of a broken down car change if you apply the same force for different lengths of time?

If we think about some real physical situations, our intuition tells us that if we apply a force to an object for longer, its final velocity will be greater. Imagine trying to push start a car. If the car is at rest and you begin pushing with a constant force, then the longer you keep pushing, the faster the car will be moving when you let go. 
The definition or formula to calculate an impulse is simply,

$$ {\vtr I}={\vtr F}{t}. $$
As force is a vector quantity so must the impulse be a vector; Newton's second law hints at this because he tells us that it is important to consider the direction in which the impulse was applied.

But what does it mean? This formula does not give us much of a sense of what impulse 
actually
 actually is or what it means. Let's go back to the idea that Newton describes in his second law of motion that 
an applied impulse acts to change the momentum of a body in the direction that the impulse is applied
 an applied impulse acts to change the momentum of a body in the direction that the impulse is applied .

When we apply an impulse to something our intuition tells us that it will change from being at rest to moving with some speed in the direction that we applied the impulse. By applying an impulse we will change its momentum from zero to some value given by its mass times its velocity and we would guess that the larger the impulse the greater the change in momentum.
Levels 1-4 If a constant force is applied to a body for a given time then the impulse is the vector quantity given by

$$ \label{imp1} \vtr {Impulse} = \vtr {I} = \vtr {force} \times \mbox{time} ={\vtr F}t $$
This relationship (equation 1 ) shows that we can increase the magnitude of the impulse by either increasing the magnitude of the force or increasing the amount of time over which we apply the force. So following Newton's Law,

$\displaystyle \mbox{Impulse} $ $\displaystyle = $ $\displaystyle \mbox{change in momentum} $
$\displaystyle $ $\displaystyle = $ $\displaystyle \mbox{final momentum} - \mbox{initial momentum} $
$\displaystyle {\vtr F}t $ $\displaystyle = $ $\displaystyle m{\vtr v}-m{\vtr u} = m({\vtr v}-{\vtr u}) $
where $\vari{m}$ is the mass of the body, $\vari{\vtr v}$ is the final velocity of the body after we have applied the impulse, $\vari{\vtr u}$ is the initial velocity of the body, $\vari{\vtr F}$ is the force that we apply and $\vari{t}$ is the time over which we apply the force. We can now see the connection to Newton's Second Law as we learn it at school if we do a little rearrangement of our formula,

$\displaystyle {\vtr F}t $ $\displaystyle = $ $\displaystyle m({\vtr v}-{\vtr u}) $
$\displaystyle {\vtr F} $ $\displaystyle = $ $\displaystyle m\frac{({\vtr v}-{\vtr u})}{t} $
A change in velocity $(v-u)$ (v-u) divided by the time it takes for that change $t$ t is the average acceleration of the body, so
$$ {\vtr F}=m{\vtr a} $$

$\displaystyle {\vtr I} $ $\displaystyle = $ $\displaystyle \frac{({\vtr F_ f}+{\vtr F_ i})t_ f}{2} \label{area_ tri} $

The graph of a force that changes over time from an initial value of 
$\vari{F_i}$
 to 
$\vari{F_f}$
 over a time of 
$\vari{t}$
 seconds. The impulse that the object experiences can be calculated using the area under the line of graph, shown in pink.

But we can also use this force-time graph to illustrate how we would calculate the impulse in a general case, when the area cannot be simply expressed because the force-time relationship is more complex. 
We can calculate the area under the force line by adding up the areas of a series of small rectangles of width 
$\vari{\d t}$
 from 
$\valuedef{t}{0}{}$
 to 
$\valuedef{t}{t_f}{}$
 . Using figure 
1
 we can see that the area of a small rectangle is given by the height of the rectangle 
$\vari{\vtr F}$
 multiplied by the width of the rectangle 
$\vari{\d t}$
 . The instantaneous impulse, 
$\vari{\d{\vtr I}}$
 at time 
$\vari{t}$
 is therefore

$$ \d{\vtr I} = {\vtr F}\d t $$
The force-time graph in figure 1 shows that the force varies with time as a straight line, so $\valuedef{\vtr F}{kt+c}{}$ , where the gradient of the line

$$ k=\frac{({\vtr F_ f}-{\vtr F_ i})}{t_ f} $$
and the vertical intercept, $\valuedef{c}{\vtr F_i}{}$ , so therefore the force at any given time is.

$$ {\vtr F}=\frac{({\vtr F_ f}-{\vtr F_ i})t}{t_ f}+{\vtr F_ i} $$
To find the total impulse we need to add up all the small areas which we can do by integrating this equation for the force over time.

$\displaystyle {\vtr I} $ $\displaystyle = $ $\displaystyle \int _0^{t_ f}{{\vtr F} \d t} $
$\displaystyle $ $\displaystyle = $ $\displaystyle \int _0^{t_ f}\left[\frac{({\vtr F_ f}-{\vtr F_ i})t}{t_ f}+{\vtr F_ i}\right] \d t $
$\displaystyle {\vtr I} $ $\displaystyle = $ $\displaystyle \left[\frac{({\vtr F_ f}-{\vtr F_ i})t^2}{2t_ f}+{\vtr F_ i}t\right]_0^{t_ f} $
$\displaystyle {\vtr I} $ $\displaystyle = $ $\displaystyle \frac{({\vtr F_ f}-{\vtr F_ i})t_ f}{2}+{\vtr F_ i}t_ f $
$\displaystyle {\vtr I} $ $\displaystyle = $ $\displaystyle \frac{({\vtr F_ f}+{\vtr F_ i})t_ f}{2} $
We can see, therefore, that integrating the equation for the force over time produces the same result as calculating the area under the graph by triangles given by equation 1 .
